name: Chenhao Liu
body:
Chenhao Liu

liuch13@mails.tsinghua.edu.cn

View My GitHub Profile

About Myself

I am an undergraduate majoring in Electronic Engineering in Tsinghua University since 2013. I am currently affiliated to 3D Image lab, under the guidance of Prof. Huimin Ma. In summer 2016, I spent six wonderful weeks working as an intern in LEMS Lab, Brown University, working with Prof. Benjamin Kimia (scored 98/100 by supervisor, 90/100 in department's overall intership grading, ranking top 10%). During my undergraduate study in Tsinghua University, I got an overall GPA of 86/100, ranking 32 among 196 students. I was active in research activities having been recruited by Tsinghua University's Student Research Training program and Top Open program. I have done several research related to computer vision and data science, and I now have three publications under revision. My research interest spans a wide range in the field of computer vision, especially in topics related to object detection, scene labeling, face analysis, and image analysis method for the above topics, such as contour extraction, image segmentation and motion detection. My dream is to make AI devices interpret visual world as accurately and efficiently as human beings. For more detalis, please see my curriculum vitae.

Projects


A Multi-Stage Approach to Curve Extraction

Countour Extraction is a fundamental topic in the field of computer vision. In order to avoid the drawback of using a global functional directly on edges, which can result in non-salient but high scoring curve fragments, we propose a multi-stage approach to contour extraction, which iteratively reduce searching space by removing unlikely candidates using geometric constrains, but without significantly affecting recall. The resulting curve fragments are typically visually salient and have been evaluated using CFGD dataset. For more details, click here.


A Multi-Stage Method of Contour Extraction.


Dataset for Shaded Object Recognition

Although current computer vision technology has witnessed great progress in object classification and detection, recognition of non-iconic objects in complex exvironments still remains an unsolved problem. Shading is the most common type of interference in the recognization of objects in context. When dealing with shaded object recognition in complex environments, we are trying to set up a dataset and a future benchmark for similar researches. When grouping the images, we consider object shaded, sh...(line truncated)...

Microexpression Analysis for Psycological Purposes

Facial expressions show a person's mood, thoughts, as well as psycological well being. Moreover, although one can possibly hold his facial expressions after training, microexpressions, propelled by neural reflex, always betray one's true feelings. We try to analyze a person's psycological status, including terms of tension, aggresiveness and fearness, by detecting the micro-movement of his facial muscles using different motion tracking methods.



Vehicular network and its applications to urban computing.
